Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: Good evening from Atlanta and welcome to the vice presidential debate sponsored by the Nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates. It’s being held here in the Theater for the Arts on the campus of Georgia Tech. I’m Hal Bruno from ABC News and I’m going to be moderating tonight’s debate. The participants are Republican Vice President Dan Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: Democratic Senator Al Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: And retired Vice Admiral James Stockdale, who is the vice presidential nominee —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: — for independent candidate Ross Perot.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: Now, the ground rules for tonight’s debate. Each candidate will have 2 minutes for an opening statement. I will then present the issues to be discussed. For each topic, the candidates will have a minute and 15 seconds to respond. Then this will be followed by a 5 minute discussion period in which they can ask questions of each other if they so choose.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: Now, the order of response has been determined by a drawing and we’ll rotate with each topic. At the end of the debate, each candidate will have 2 minutes for a closing statement.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: Our radio and TV audience should know that the candidates were given an equal allocation of auditorium seats for their supporters. So I’d like to ask the audience here in the theater to please refrain from applause or any partisan demonstration once the debate is under way because it takes time away from the candidates. So with that plea from your moderator let’s get started.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: HAL BRUNO
Text: And we’ll turn first to Senator Gore for his opening statement.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: SENATOR GORE
Text: Good evening. It’s great to be here in Atlanta for this debate where America will be showcased to the world when the 1996 Olympics are put on right here. It’s appropriate because in a real sense, our discussion this evening will be about what kind of nation we want to be 4 years from now. It’s also a pleasure to be with my 2 opponents this evening. Admiral Stockdale, may I say it’s a special honor to share this stage with you. Those of us who served in Vietnam looked at you as a national hero even before you were awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: SENATOR GORE
Text: And Mr. Vice President — Dan, if I may — it was 16 years ago that you and I went to the Congress on the very first day together. I’ll make you a deal this evening. If you don’t try to compare George Bush to Harry Truman, I won’t compare you to Jack Kennedy.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: SENATOR GORE
Text: Harry Truman —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: VICE PRESIDENT QUAYLE
Text: Do you remember the last time someone compared themselves to Jack Kennedy? Do you remember what they said?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Harry Truman, it’s worth remembering, assumed the presidency when Franklin Roosevelt died here in Georgia — only one of many occasions when fate thrust a vice president into the Oval Office in a time of crisis. It’s something to think about during the debate this evening. But our real discussion is going to be about change. Bill Clinton and I stand for change because we don’t believe our nation can stand 4 more years of what we’ve had under George Bush and Dan Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: When the recession came they were like a deer caught in the headlights — paralyzed into inaction, blinded to the suffering and pain of bankruptcies and people who were unemployed. We have an environmental crisis, a health insurance crisis, substandard education. It is time for a change.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I want to get our country moving forward again, put our people back to work, and create a bright future for the US of America.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, the next statement will be from Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, thank you, Senator Gore, for reminding me about my performance in the 1988 vice presidential debate. This is 1992, Bill Clinton is running against President George Bush. There are 2 things that I’m going to stress during this debate: one, Bill Clinton’s economic plan and his agenda will make matters much, much worse — he will raise your taxes, he will increase spending, he will make government bigger, jobs will be lost; second, Bill Clinton does not have the strength nor the character to be president of the US.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let us look at the agendas. President Bush wants to hold the line on taxes, Bill Clinton wants to raise taxes. President Bush is for a balanced budget amendment, Bill Clinton is opposed to it. We want to reform the legal system because it’s too costly, Bill Clinton wants the status quo. We want to reform the health care system, Bill Clinton wants to ration health care. Bill Clinton wants to empower government, we want to empower people.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: In St. Louis, Missouri, in June of this year, Bill Clinton said this - “America is the mockery of the world.” He is wrong.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: At some time during these next 4 years there is going to be a crisis — there will be an international crisis. I can’t tell you where it’s going to be, I can’t even tell you the circumstances — but it will happen. We need a president who has the experience, who has been tested, who has the integrity and qualifications to handle the crisis. The president has been tested, the president has the integrity and the character. The choice is yours.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You need to have a president you can trust. Can you really trust Bill Clinton?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale, your opening statement, please, sir?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: Who am I? Why am I here?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: (Laughter and applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: I’m not a politician — everybody knows that. So don’t expect me to use the language of the Washington insider. Thirty-seven years in the Navy, and only one of them up there in Washington. And now I’m an academic.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: The centerpiece of my life was the Vietnam War. I was there the day it started. I led the first bombing raid against North Vietnam. I was there the day it ended, and I was there for everything in between. Ten years in Vietnam, aerial combat, and torture. I know things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world. I know some things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: And I know how governments, how American governments can be — can be courageous, and how they can be callow. And that’s important. That’s one thing I’m an insider on.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: I was the leader of the underground of the American pilots who were shot down in prison in North Vietnam. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom, learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: ADMIRAL STOCKDALE
Text: Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Thank you, Admiral. I thought since you’re running for vice president, that we ought to start off by talking about the vice presidency itself. The vice president presides over the Senate, he casts a deciding vote in case of a tie, but his role really depends on the assignments that are given to him by the president. However, if a president should die in office, or is unable to serve for any other reason, the vice president automatically becomes president, and that has happened 5 times in this century.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: So the proposition I put on the table for you to discuss is this.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: What role would each of you like to play as vice president, what areas interest you, and what are your qualifications to serve as president, if necessary?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: In the case of Vice President Quayle, who we’re starting with, I suppose you’d tell us the role that you did play in the first term and which you’d like to do in a 2nd term. Go ahead, sir.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, then I won’t give you that answer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Qualifications. I’ve been there, Hal. I’ve done the job. I’ve been tested. I’ve been vice president for 4 years. Senator Gore referred to us being elected to the Congress together in 1976. I’ve done the job. I’ve done many things for the president.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But even as vice president you never know exactly what your role is going to be from time to time, and let me just give you an example of where I was tested under fire and in a crisis.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: President Bush was flying to Malta in 1989 to meet with President Gorbachev. It was the first meeting between President Bush and President Gorbachev. They had known each other before.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: A coup broke out in the Philippines. I had to go to the situation room. I had to assemble the president’s advisers. I talked to President Aquino. I made the recommendation to the president. The president made the decision, the coup was suppressed, democracy continued in the Philippines, the situation was ended.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’ve been there. And I’ll tell you one other thing that qualifies you for being president — and it’s this, Hal — you’ve got to stand up for what you believe in. And nobody has ever criticized me for not having strong beliefs.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: My association with Mr. Perot is a very personal one and as I have stood in and finally taken his running mate position, he has granted me total autonomy. I don’t take advantage of it, but I am sure that he would make me a partner in decision, in making decisions about the way to handle health care, the way to get this economy back on its feet again, in every way.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I have not had the experience of these gentlemen, but — to be any more specific — but I know I have his trust, and I intend to act in a way to keep that situation alive. Thank you.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton understands the meaning of the words “teamwork” and “partnership.” If we’re successful in our efforts to gain your trust and lead this nation, we will work together to put our country back on the right track again. The experience that George Bush and Dan Quayle have been talking about includes the worst economic performance since the Great Depression. Unemployment is up, personal income is down, bankruptcies are up, housing starts are down. How long can we continue with trickle-down economics when the record of failure is so abundantly clear?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Discussions of the vice presidency tend sometimes to focus on the crisis during which a vice president is thrust into the Oval Office, and indeed, one-3rd of the vice presidents who have served have been moved into the White House.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But the teamwork and partnership beforehand — and hopefully that situation never happens — how you work together is critically important. The way we work together in this campaign is one sample.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now I’d like to say in response to Vice President Quayle- -he talked about Malta and the Philippines. George Bush has concentrated on every other country in the world. When are you guys going to start worrying about our people here in the US of America and get our country moving again?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Again, I will ask the audience: please do not applaud, it takes time from the candidates. All right, now we have 5 minutes for discussion. Go ahead, Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: The answer to that is very simple: we are not going to raise taxes to create new jobs, we have a plan to create new jobs. But that wasn’t the question. The question dealt with qualifications. Teamwork and partnership may be fine in the Congress, Senator Gore — that’s what Congress is all about, compromise, teamwork, working things out. But when you’re president of the US or when you’re vice president and you have to fill in like I did the night of the crisis in the Philippines, you’ve got to make a decision, you’ve got to make up your mind. Bill Clinton, running for president of the US, said this about the Persian Gulf war. He said: “Had I been in the Senate, I would have voted with the majority, if it was a close vote. But I agreed with the arguments of the minority.”

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You can’t have it both ways, you have to make a decision. You cannot sit there in an international crisis —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — and sit there and say, well, on the one hand, this is okay, and, on the other hand, this is okay. You’ve got to make the decision. President Bush has made the decisions; he’s been tested, he’s got the experience, he’s got the qualification, he’s got the integrity to be our president for the next 4 years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Thank you, Mr. Vice President. Admiral Stockdale, it’s your turn to respond next, and then Senator Gore will have his chance to respond.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Okay. I thought this was just an open session, this 5-minute thing, and I didn’t have anything to add to his. But I will —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, I’ll jump in if you don’t want —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I thought anyone could jump in whenever they wanted to.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, whatever pleases you gentlemen is fine with me. You’re the candidates.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But I want Admiral Stockdale’s time.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: (Laughter and applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: This is not the Senate, where you can trade off time. Go ahead, Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I’ll let you all figure out the rules, I’ve got some points that I want to make here, and I still haven’t gotten an answer to my question on when you guys are going to start worrying about this country, but I want to elaborate on it before —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Why doesn’t the Democratic Congress — why doesn’t the Democratic Congress pass the presidentâ€™s bill?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Mr. Vice President, let him say his thoughts, and then you can come in.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I was very patient in letting you get off that string of attacks. We’ve been listening to —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Good points.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — trickle-down economics for 12 years now, and you all still support trickle-down to the very last drop. And, you know, talking about this point of concentrating on every other country in the world as opposed to the people of our country right here at home, when George Bush took former Secretary of State Baker out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the campaign and made him chief of staff in the White, Mr. Baker, who’s quite a capable man, said that for these last 4 years George Bush was working on the problems of the rest of the world and in the next 4 years he would target America. Well, I want you to know we really appreciate that. But Bill Clinton and I will target America from day one. We won’t wait 4 years before we concentrate on the problems in this country. He went on to say that it’s really amazing what George Bush can do when he concentrates. Well, it’s time that we had a president like Bill Clinton who can concentrate and will concentrate and work on the problems of real people in this country. You know, our country is in trouble. We simply cannot continue with this philosophy of giving huge tax cuts to the very wealthy, raising taxes on middle income families the way Bush and Quayle have done and then waiting for it to work. How much longer will it take, Dan, for trickle down economics to work, in your theory?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, we’re going to have plenty of time to talk about trickle down government, which you’re for. But the question —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, I’d like to hear the answer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But the question is — the question is — and which you have failed to address, and that is, why is Bill Clinton qualified to be president of the US. You’ve talked about —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Oh, I’ll be happy to answer that question —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You’ve talked about Jim Baker. You’ve talked about trickle down economics. You’ve talked about the worst economy-

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Now, wait a minute. The question was about —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — in 50 years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I’ll be happy to answer those. May I answer —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Why is he qualified to be president of the US?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I’ll be happy to —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I want to go back and make a point —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, you’ve asked me the question. If you won’t answer my question I will answer yours.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I have not asked you a question. I’ve made a statement. I have not asked you a question, Iâ€™ve made a statement that you have not told us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president of the US. I pointed out what he said about the Persian Gulf War. But let me repeat it for you. Here’s what he said, Senator. You know full well what he said.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You want me to answer your question?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’m making a statement. Then you can answer it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Can we give Admiral Stockdale a chance to come in, please —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: And again, audience —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: (Simultaneous conversation)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: (Inaudible) here’s what he said. I mean, this is the Persian Gulf War — the most important event in his political lifetime and here’s what Bill Clinton says. If it’s a close vote, I’d vote with the majority.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s give Admiral Stockdale a chance to come in.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But he was the minority. That qualifies you for being president of the US. I hope America is listening very closely to this debate tonight.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: And I think America is seeing right now the reason this nation is in gridlock.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: (Laughter, applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: The trickle downs and the tax and spends, or whatever you want to call them are at swords points. We can’t get this economy going. Over here we’ve got Dan whose president is going to take 8 years to balance the budget and on my left, the senator, whose boss is going to get it half way balanced in 4 years. Ross Perot has got a plan to balance the budget 5 years in length from start to finish. And we’re — people of the non-professional category who are just sick of this terrible thing that’s happened to the country. And we’ve got a man who knows how to fix it, and I’m working for him.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: I was a little bit worried that there might not be a free flowing discussion tonight.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s move on to the economy. Specifically the economy was talked about at great length the other night in the presidential debate. Let’s talk about a very particular aspect of the economy and that is, getting people back to work. For the average person, the great fear is losing his or her job and many Americans have lost jobs in this recession, which also means the loss of benefits, the loss of a home, the destruction of a family’s security. Specifically, how would your administration go about getting people back to work and how long is it going to take? And we start with Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: The lifeblood of our economy is investment. And right now when we pay $350 — we borrow $350 billion a year it saps the money markets and the private investors are not getting their share. What we do is work on that budget by an aggressive program, not a painful program, so that we can start borrowing less money and getting more investment money on the street through entrepreneurs who can build factories, who will hire people, and maybe we’ll start manufacturing goods here in this country again. That’s — that’s my answer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay. Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton’s top priority is putting America back to work. Bill Clinton and I will create good, high-wage jobs for our people, the same way he has done in his state. Bill Clinton has created high-wage manufacturing jobs at 10 times the national average and in fact according to the statistics coming from the Bush-Quayle Labor Dept, for the last 2 years in a role Bill Clinton’s state has been number one among all 50 in the creation of jobs in the private sector.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: By contrast, in the nation as a whole, during the last 4 years, it is the first time since the presidency of Herbert Hoover, that we have gone for a 4-year period with fewer jobs at the end of that 4-year period than we had at the beginning.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And look at manufacturing. We have lost 1.4 million jobs in manufacturing under George Bush and Dan Quayle. They have even — we learned 2 weeks ago — taken our tax dollars and subsidized the moving of US factories to foreign countries. Now don’t deny it because 60 Minutes and Nightline and the nation’s newspapers have investigated this very carefully.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter.)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move ’em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Senator, don’t always believe what you see on television.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let me tell you - the media have been wrong before. We have never subsidized any country — or any company to move from the US to Latin America. You know full well the Caribbean Basin Initiative, you’ve supported that.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: That is a program there —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I voted against it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You voted for it and your record —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Okay. Well, we’ll — we’ll have a lot of interesting debate after this debate. Our people will be glad to furnish the press, if they’re interested, in Senator Gore’s voting record on the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But let’s talk — you know, you keep talking about trickle-down economics and all this stuff, about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It’s a tough economy. The question isn’t — it’s not who you’re going to blame; itâ€™s what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much, much worse.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral. We now throw it open for discussion. Admiral Stockdale, it’s your turn to start the discussion.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Well, we’ve got to re — we’ve got to clean out the barn, if I may quote my boss, and start getting this investment money on the street so we can get, and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We — the program is out there. It’s a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice, but not excessive, and we are willing to move forward in — on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get — get this nation straightened out.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore, getting people back to work.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot’s plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit, and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs, cut the budget deficit in half, and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail, for example, and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities, not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But I want to return and say one more time - you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville, Tennessee, not very far from my home, a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers’ money, and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: When are you going to stop that program?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we’ve got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this, Senator, that every job that’s overseas there’s 3 jobs back here to support that.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But never have we ever, nor would we, support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That’s just totally ridiculous.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: It’s going on right now; it happened in Tennessee, in Decaturville, Tennessee. When George Bush went to Nashville, the employees who lost their jobs asked to meet with —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I want to get back —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they’re feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they’re going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You got that wrong, too.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And the first — that is part of your plan.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No, it’s not.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well, you’re going to disavow your plan.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Listen, what we’re proposing —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You know what you’re doing, you know what you’re doing? You’re pulling a Clinton.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is, is what he says — he says one thing one day and another thing the next day — you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No, we’re not.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — and told them that —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You can say it all you want but it doesn’t make it true.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I’m sure what you didn’t talk to them about was about how we’re going to reform the health care system, like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’m sure one other thing that you didn’t talk to them about, Senator, and that is legal reform, because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That’s not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won’t pass it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay. I think it’s time to move on to our next topic. All 3 of you gentlemen have some expertise in defense and the armed forces. Vice President Quayle and Senator Gore both served on the Senate Armed Services Committee. Admiral Stockdale, of course, has a very distinguished military career.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: With the end of the Cold War, everyone agrees that there are going to be major cuts. They’ve already started in the defense budget. But this country has a long history of neglecting its military needs in peace time and then paying for it with heavy casualties when we’re caught unprepared. How much of a defense cut is safe? What happens to the people who are forced to leave the military services, or if they lose their jobs because they’re working in defense industries.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: I think we start with Senator Gore this time.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War, the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example, George Bush wants to maintain at least 150,000 American soldiers in Europe, even though World War II ended 50 years ago.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans, who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time, improve our national security.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now, for those who are affected by the cutbacks, whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me — the difference is, Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work, building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the ’90’s and the next century.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn’t win the Cold — we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes, we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I’d say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere, a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Yes, we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense — or the defense industry. Well, let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd, and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude — if you would have supported that attitude, we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Mr. — Admiral Stockdale, please.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Yes, thanks. The numbers, in terms of the dollar cuts, as they stand on our plans now, show us almost the same as the vice president’s. But we’d note that Mr. — Governor Clinton’s plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I’ve been through the end of World War II, and the surprise beginning of Korea, to see how we — it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don’t say that —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion, people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Now there’s other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me, and that has to do with we want to focus our interests, economic and military, more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that’s still another face of this puzzle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore, would you like to start the discussion period on this topic?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Yeah, I’d like to respond first to you, Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan, we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle, but only 5 % more.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Admiral Crowe, who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Oh, yes, I’ve known him —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — has endorsed —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: — 50 years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — the military portions of our plan, even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush, and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan, even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot’s economic plan.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston, that when he heard the phrase “we won the Cold War,” it made him wonder who the “we” was. Well, I want to tell you, President Bush, the “we” is the people of the US of America. This wasn’t a partisan victory that came suddenly, a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And I want to, I want to add — I want to add one other thing, because in the debate a few nights ago, I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone, Ross, that’s done. He — he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal, but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign, the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Isn’t it a fact, Dan, that every single one of those SS-18s is still there, in the silos, and under the START I treaty, only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled, and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Didn’t the president make a mistake there?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle, please.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Is it an agreement?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It is a commitment.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Oh.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let’s talk about, let’s talk about —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, he said he’d —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let him talk, Senator.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Lighten up here, Al.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: (Laughter and applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let’s talk about getting agreements. You know, the president of the US doesn’t just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He’s got to deal with the president of Russia, he’s got to deal with the chancellor of Germany, the prime minister of Britain, the president of France, the prime minister of Japan — he’s got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate, and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton, is trust and character.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it’s the fact — it’s the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn’t get an induction notice, then we find out that he did; he said he didn’t have an ROTC slot, then we find out he did; he said he didn’t use Senator Fulbright’s office for special influence, then we find out that he did.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand, because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I want to respond to that, I want to respond to that. George Bush, in case you’ve forgotten, Dan, said “Read my lips — no new taxes.”

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter and applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And you know what?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I didn’t think I was going to hear that tonight.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Hold on, hold on, let me finish.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Okay.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: He also said he wanted to be the environmental president; then he went on to say he wanted to be the education president. Then he said that he wouldn’t raise taxes again — no, never, ever, ever. Then the next day his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, came out and said that’s not a pledge. Then 2 weeks ago he said that after the election, if you win, then James Baker’s going to go back to be secretary of state; then a week later, in the debate a few nights ago, he said, no, after the election, if we win, James Baker is going to be in charge of domestic policy.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Which is it, Dan? Is he going to — what’s your role in this going to be?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter and applause)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Well, we’ll have to move on to another topic.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let me —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Sorry, Mr. Vice President.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I don’t have time to respond to that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: You’ll get plenty of chance to respond, so don’t worry.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Okay, you’re the moderator. I was under the assumption that when the thing is like that that you get a chance to respond.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Well, we ran out of time; according to the agreement, it’s time to move on. And I want to stick to the agreement.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Okay. Well, you got the last word on that, but we’ll come back to it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: But you’ll have a chance — I can see what’s happening here: we throw out the topic and then we drift. But that’s okay, because I think it’s making for a healthy exchange.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: The only thing I would ask of you —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I’m enjoying it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: The only thing I would ask of you gentlemen is that when we get to the discussion period, whoever talks first be considerate of the others, because you have a tendency to filibuster.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Look over there.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, I’m not pointing any fingers. Let’s talk about the environment — we’ll get away from controversy.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Everyone wants a safe and clean environment, but there’s an ongoing conflict between environmental protection and the need for economic growth and jobs. So the point I throw out on the table is, how do you resolve this conflict between protection of the environment and growth in jobs, and why has it taken so long to deal with basic problems, such as toxic waste dumps, clean air and clean water?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: And, Vice President Quayle, it’s your turn to start first.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Hal, that’s a false choice. You don’t have to have a choice between the environment and jobs — you can have both. Look at the president’s record: clean air legislation passed the Democratic Congress because of the leadership of George Bush. It is the most comprehensive clean air act in our history. We are firmly behind preserving our environment, and we have a good record with which to stand. The question comes about: What is going to be their position when it comes to the environment? I say it’s a false choice. You ought to ask somebody in Michigan, a UAW worker in Michigan, if they think increasing the CAFE standards, the fuel economy standards, to 45 miles a gallon is a good idea — 300,000 people out of work. You ought to talk to the timber people in the Northwest where they say that, well, we can only save the owl, forget about jobs.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You ought to talk to the coal miners. They’re talking about putting a coal tax on. They’re talking about a tax on utilities, a tax on gasoline and home heating oil — all sorts of taxes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: No, Hal, the choice isn’t the environment and jobs. With the right policies — prudent policies — we can have both.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I read Senator Gore’s book about the environment and I don’t see how he could possibly pay for his proposals in today’s economic climate.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: You know, the Marshall Plan of the environment, and so forth.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: And also, I’m told by some experts that the things that he fears most might not be all that dangerous, according to some scientists. You know, you can overdo, I’m told, environmental cleaning up. If you purify the pond, the water lilies die. You know, I love this planet and I want it to stay here, but I don’t like to have it the private property of fanatics that want to overdo this thing.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I believe we can create millions of new jobs by leading the environmental revolution instead of dragging our feet and bringing up the rear.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You know, Japan and Germany are both opening proclaiming to the world now that the biggest new market in the history of world business is the market for the new products and technologies that foster economic progress without environmental destruction.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Why is the Japanese business organization — the largest one they have, the Ki Den Ren (phonetic), arguing for tougher environmental standards than those embodied in US law? Why is MITI — their trade organization — calling on all Japanese corporations everywhere in the world to exceed by as much as possible the environmental standards of every country in which they’re operating?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, maybe they’re just dumb about business competition. But maybe they know something that George Bush and Dan Quayle don’t know — that the future will call for greater efficiency and greater environmental efficiency.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: This is a value an issue that touches my basic values. I’m taught in my religious tradition that we are given dominion over the Earth, but we’re required to be good stewards of the Earth, and that means to take care of it. We’re not doing that now under the Bush-Quayle policies. They have gutted the Clean Air Act. They have broken his pledge to be the environmental president. Bill Clinton and I will change that.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay. Discussion period now. Again, leave time for each other, please. Vice President Quayle, go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, I’m tempted to yield to Admiral Stockdale on this. But I — you know, the fact of the matter is that one of the proposals that Senator Gore has suggested is to have the taxpayers of America spend $100 billion a year on environmental projects in foreign countries —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: That’s not true —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Foreign aid — well, Senator, it’s in your book. On page 304 —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No, it’s not.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It is there.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It is in your book. You know, Hal, I wanted to bring the Gore book tonight, because I figured he was going to pull a Bill Clinton on me and he has. Because he’s going to disavow what’s in his book. It’s in your book —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It comes out to $100 billion of foreign aid for environmental projects.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: All right. Let’s give him a chance to answer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Now, how are we going to pay for it? How are we going to pay for an extra $100 billion of the taxpayers’ money for this?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Dan, I appreciate you reading my book very much, but you’ve got it wrong.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: No, I’ve got it right.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: There’s no such proposal.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Okay, well, we’ll find —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let him talk, Mr Vice President. Let the senator talk. Go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: There is no such proposal. What I have called upon is a cooperative effort by the US and Europe and Asia to work together in opening up new markets throughout the world for the new technologies that are necessary in order to reconcile the imperatives of economic progress with the imperatives of environmental protection. Take Mexico City for an example. They are shutting down factories right now, not because of their economy, but because they’re choking to death on the air pollution. They’re banning automobiles some days of the week.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now what they want is not new laser-guided missile systems. What they want are new engines and new factories and new products that don’t pollute the air and the water, but nevertheless allow them to have a decent standard of living for their people. Last year 35 % of our exports went to developing countries, countries where the population is expanding worldwide by as much as one billion people every ten years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We cannot stick our heads in the sand and pretend that we don’t face a global environmental crisis, nor should we assume that it’s going to cost jobs. Quite the contrary. We are going to be able to create jobs as Japan and Germany are planning to do right now, if we have the guts to leave.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now earlier we heard about the auto industry and the timber industry. There have been 250,000 jobs lost in the automobile industry during the Reagan-Bush-Quayle years. There have been tens of thousands of jobs lost in the timber industry. What they like to do is point the finger of blame with one hand and hand out pink slips with the other hand. They’ve done a poor job both with the economy and the environment.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: It’s time for a change.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale, you had something you wanted to say here?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I know that — I read where Senator Gore’s mentor had disagree with some of the scientific data that is in his book. How do you respond to those criticisms of that sort? Do you —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Deny it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter.)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Do you take this into account?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: (Laughter.)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: No, I — let me respond. Thank you, Admiral, for saying that. You’re talking about Roger Revelle. His family wrote a lengthy letter saying how terribly he had been misquoted and had his remarks taken completely out of context just before he died.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Jeers.)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: He believed up until the day he died — no, it’s true, he died last year —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: I’d ask the audience to stop, please.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — and just before he died, he co- authored an article which was — had statements taken completely out of context. In fact the vast majority of the world’s scientists — and they have worked on this extensively — believe that we must have an effort to face up to the problems we face with the environment. And if we just stick out heads in the sand and pretend that it’s not real, we’re not doing ourselves a favor. Even worse than that, we’re telling our children and all future generations that we weren’t willing to face up to this obligation.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Hal, can I —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I believe that we have a mandate —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Sure. We’ve still got time.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — to try to solve this problem, particularly when we can do it while we create jobs in the process.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead, Mr. Vice President, there’s still time. Not much, though.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I know it. We’ve got to have a little equal time here now, Hal. In the book you also suggest taxes on gasoline, taxes on utilities, taxes on carbon, taxes on timber. There’s a whole host of taxes. And I don’t just — I don’t believe raising taxes is the way to solve our environmental problems.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And you talk about the bad situation in the auto industry. You seem to say that the answer is, well, I’ll just make it that much worse by increasing the CAFE standards. Yes, the auto industry is hurting, it’s been hurting for a long time, and increasing the CAFE standards to 45 miles per gallon, like you and Bill Clinton are suggesting, will put, as I said, 300,000 people out of work.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, let’s move on now. I would like to remind the audience of one thing. Trying to stop you from applauding may be a lost cause. I didn’t say anything about hissing, but I do think it is discourteous, and there’s no call for that, and it reflects badly on the candidate you’re supporting. So let’s knock that off.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s go on to health care. Health care protection has become a necessity of life in our society, yet millions of Americans are not ensured and the cost of medical treatment is practically out of control.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: How do you propose to control these costs and how are you going to provide access to health care for every American?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s see, whose turn is it to go now?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I think it’s Admiral Stockdale’s.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: I think it’s Admiral Stockdale’s turn to go first. Go ahead, sir.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Well, we have excellent technical health care, but we don’t administer it very well, and the escalating costs top any other budget danger in the — on the horizon, I think. And what Mr Perot has suggested is that we try to re- -to look at the incentives, the incentives that are in our current way of doing business, are what are killing us. There’s — there’s no incentive for a hypochondriac not to go to the — to Medicare every day. There is no incentive for a doctor to curtail the expensive tests because he’s under threat of malpractice lawyers.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: And so we — we just have a web of wrong-way incentives that has to be changed by some people who are in the medical profession and some other crafty people who know how to write contracts to change incentives or get — get the — the incentives situation under control.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I believe that if a criminal has the right to a lawyer, every American family ought to have the right to see a doctor of their own choosing when they need to see a doctor. There are almost 40 million Americans who work full time today and yet have no health insurance whatsoever. We are proposing to change that, not with a government-run plan, not with new taxes, but with a new approach called managed competition.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We are going to provide a standard health insurance package provided by private insurance companies and eliminate the duplication and red tape, and overlap, and we’re going to have cost controls to eliminate the unnecessary procedures that are costing so much money today.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: There was a bipartisan commission evenly divided between Republicans and Democrats who looked at our plan and the Bush-Quayle proposal. They said ours will save tens of billions of dollars and cover every American. The Bush proposal, by contrast, will cost us tens of billions and still leave Americans uninsured.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But what I want to know is, why has George Bush waited for 3 and a half years during this health insurance crisis before finally coming out with a proposal, just before the election, and he still hasn’t introduced it in Congress. Why the long wait, Dan?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Mr Vice President.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Hal, President Bush has had his health care reform agenda on Capitol Hill for 8 months. He’s had parts of it up there for years. You talk about increasing costs that the president has had on Capitol Hill- – medical malpractice reform legislation — for several years. Defensive medicine and health care today cost $20.7 billion. Defense medicine defined as testing and treatment that is only necessary in case of a law suit. Wouldn’t that be nice to take $20.7 billion that we’re putting into our legal system and put it to preventive health care or women’s health care or something else besides trial lawyers?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But no — you don’t want to reform the health care system to drive down costs through medical malpractice. What you’re doing — you are talking about a government program. Your program is to ration health care. You said in your statement to see a doctor when you want to see a doctor. When you start rationing health care there’s going to be a waiting line to see a doctor unless it’s an emergency.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Remember when we rationed energy in this country? Waiting lines at the gasoline stations. The same thing would happen when you ration health care. The president’s proposal deals with tax credits, deductions and purchasing health care in the private sector and making health care affordable and available to every single American.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale, would you like to start the discussion period?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Well, I’m out of ammunition on this —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, let me talk then because I’ve got a couple of things that I want to say.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead, Senator.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We still didn’t get an answer to the question of why George Bush waited for 3 and a half years —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: He didn’t wait 3 and a half years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — during the national —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I did answer the question.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — health insurance crisis before he even made a proposal. And it still hasn’t been submitted to Congress in the form of legislation. I also want to respond to the question about malpractice. Do you know which state has the lowest malpractice premiums in the entire country? Bill Clinton’s Arkansas does — partly because he has passed reform measures limiting the time during which malpractice suits can be filed. In fact, tort claims generally have fallen 10 % under Bill Clinton there.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But you know, that’s not the reason for this health insurance crisis. The reason is, we’ve had absolutely no leadership. Let me tell you about a friend of mine named Mitch Philpot from Marietta, Georgia — not far from here — who Tipper and I met with his family in Johns Hopkins Hospital. Their son, Brett, was in the bed next to our son and they couldn’t pay their medical bills. They used to live in Atlanta, but they lost their house. And while they were there, both Mitch and his wife lost their jobs because they could not get unpaid leave.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We pass legislation to give family leave under circumstances like that, exempting small business. How can you talk about family values, Dan, and twice veto the Family Medical Leave Act?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Mr Vice President.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Pass our Family Leave Act, because it goes to small businesses where the major problem is. Your proposal excluded small business. That’s the problem.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Now, let me talk about health care and —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Did you require it? Did you require it?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: My turn — (holding hand up at Gore)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Did you require (inaudible) —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Simultaneous conversation)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Lightenâ€™ up Al. My turn.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: It’s a free discussion.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Take a breath, Al. Inhale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: It’s a free discussion.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Did you require family leave in that legislation? Yes or no?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We offered incentives to small businesses. Yes or no —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: That’s a no, isn’t it?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Was small business exempted under your proposal?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Yes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Yes. And that’s where the biggest problem is —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Did you require it of anyone?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’m going to get back to the topic again —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Did you require it of anyone?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — because he obviously doesn’t want to talk about health insurance or health care, which you address. I was absolutely — I shouldn’t say that — another Clinton. You pulled another Clinton on me because here you go again. Medical malpractice legislation has been before the Congress of the US and you tried to convince the American people that Bill Clinton is for tort reform? The biggest campaign contributors to your campaign are the trial lawyers of America. We have a letter — and we’re going to release it again to the media, if the media is interested — where the head of the trial lawyers of Arkansas said that Bill Clinton was basically in their back pocket, that Bill Clinton has always opposed tort reform of any kind. It’s in the letter, we have it, we’ll make it available — because Bill Clinton is not for tort reform.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’d like to know where Bill Clinton stands on health insurance. When he was campaigning in New Hampshire, he said I am for the pay-or-play health insurance. Pay or play, that’s a 7 to 9 % payroll tax on every worker in America that participates in this program.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Can I respond?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And then, all of a sudden, this summer he says, oh, I’m not for a pay or play. Here we go again. Bill Clinton, one day he’s for pay or play, the next day he’s against pay or play. He does it in education. He writes Polly Williams, a Democrat state legislator in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, saying I’m for choice in education; then he goes to the NEA teachers union and says, sorry, I’m not for choice in education because you won’t let me be for choice in education.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: One time Bill Clinton says term limits — we ought to limit terms, it’s ridiculous that a member of Congress can serve for 30, 40, 50 years, and you limit the terms of the president — but that’s another subject.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We’re fixing to limit one.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: It’s not going to be mine; it’s going to be people like you and Kennedy and Metzenbaum and George Mitchell and the rest of that Democratic Congress on Capitol Hill — that’s who we’re talking about.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And that’s who the American people — as you well know, you’ve got term limits for a president, you don’t have term limits for Congress, and I think it’s absolutely ridiculous that we don’t.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I want to respond to some of this.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Here goes Bill Clinton again: he says, well, term limits, that’s an interesting idea, I think I might be in favor of that. Then his Democratic friends in Congress say, no, Bill, you can’t be for that.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. You have to tell the truth.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I want to respond, if I might.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead, Senator, quickly.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You know, in response to my question before that long laundry list, he said that they had their own family leave proposal. It was just like the proposal of your party back when Social Security was first proposed. You said: we’re for it as long as it’s voluntary. Same with Medicare. You said: we’re for it so long as it’s voluntary. Civil rights — we’re for it so long as it’s voluntary.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator, I’m going to have to ask you to wrap this one up.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Family leave is important enough to be required.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, thanks. Coming out of health care, again trying to avoid controversy, let’s talk about the abortion debate.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Abortion rights has been a bitter controversy in this country for almost 20 years. It’s been heightened by the recent Supreme Court decisions. So I’ll make it very simple in this question: Where do each of you stand on the issue? What actions will your president’s administration take on the abortion question? Will it be a factor in the appointment of federal judges, especially to the Supreme Court? And I believe that Senator Gore goes first.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: That doesn’t mean we’re pro-abortion; in fact, we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies, not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman’s right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege — but don’t have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: But, Dan, you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me - I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle, your turn.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — in public life. My objective and the president’s objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington, DC, than we do live births. Why shouldn’t we have more reflection upon the issue before abor — the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period, parental notification.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said — she said I wished at that time, that I was going through this difficult time, that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma, and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion, I would have had the child. Let’s not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country, in this country of ours.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I believe that a woman owns her body and what she does with it is her own business, period.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Period.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: That’s it?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I don’t — I, too, abhor abortions, but I don’t think they should be made illegal, and I don’t — and I don’t think it’s a political issue. I think it’s a privacy issue.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: You caught me by surprise. Let’s go ahead with the discussion of this issue. Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, you notice in his response, that Dan did not say I support the right of a woman to choose. That is because he and George Bush have turned over their party to Pat Buchanan and Phyllis Schlafly, who have ordered them to endorse a platform which makes all abortions illegal under any circumstances, regardless of what has led to that decision by a woman.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Even in cases of rape and incest, their platform requires that a woman be penalized, that she not be allowed to make a choice, if she believes, in consultation with her family, her doctor, and others, whoever she chooses, that she wants to have an abortion after rape, or incest. They make it completely —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Senator, do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — illegal under any of those circumstances.
