Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now they want to waffle around —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Let me finish this, briefly. Now — now you want to waffle around on it and give the impression that maybe you don’t really mean what you say. But again, you can clear it up by simply repeating I support the right of a woman to choose. Say it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let him say it himself. Let him say his own words. Go ahead, Mr Vice President.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Thank you. Talk about waffling around. This issue is a very important issue. It has been debated throughout your public life and throughout my public life, and one thing that I don’t think that it is wise to do, and that is to change your position.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: At one time, and most of the time in the House of Representatives, you had a pro-life position.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: That’s simply not true.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: In 1987, you wrote a letter, and we’ll pass this out to the media —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: That is simply not true.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You wrote a letter saying that you oppose taxpayer funding of abortion. Bill Clinton has the same type of a record.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: In some circumstances.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: You’re going to qualify it now.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And I still do.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And Bill Clinton, when he was governor of Arkansas, also worked with the Right to Life people and supported Right to Life positions and now he has changed. Talk about waffling around. This is the typical type of Clinton response. Even on the issue like abortion. He’s on both sides of the issue.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Take the NAFTA agreement —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, wait —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s stick with the question, Mr Vice President.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: How long did he have —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I know you want to change the subject, Dan, but let’s stay on this one for a while.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: How long did he have to wait — or how quickly did he change his position on education? He changes his position all the time.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Let’s stay with this issue for a while.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Bill Clinton — Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. 3 words he fears most in the English language.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Does anybody have any view about the appointment of judges on this?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Tell the truth.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Yeah, I want to talk about this, because the question was not about free trade or education. The question —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Talk about waffling. You’re the one who brought up the —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now, I let you talk.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — issue of waffling. He’s waffled on the abortion issue.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I let you talk. Let me talk now. It’s going to be a long evening if you’re like this, now.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Oh, no, it’s not —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Don’t change the subject —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s get on with it. Gentlemen, let’s get on with it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Don’t change the subject —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, answer my questions, then.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: What you have done —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Answer my questions. On the 24 hour waiting period — do you support that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I have had the same position —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Do you support that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I have had the same position on abortion in favor of a woman’s right to choose. Do you support a woman’s right to choose —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Do you support a 24 hour waiting period to have —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: You’re still avoiding —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: How about avoiding the question?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — the question. Now, wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And if you support them, don’t be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know, one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they’ve turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don’t even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Again, can’t you just say you support the right of a woman to choose?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Could we give Admiral Stockdale a chance to jump in here if he wants to, if he dares to.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I would like to get in — I feel like I’m an observer at a pingpong game, where they’re talking about well, you know, they’re expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to ’em. And meantime, we’re facing a desperate situation in our economy. I’ve seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family — my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have — that is, the Perot group — the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact, her children will be dead before another — this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let’s get on with talking about something substantive.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: All right. Mr Vice President, you’ll have a chance to —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: You’ll have a chance in the closing statements.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We need to get on —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: No, let’s move on to another topic.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Just 15 seconds to respond.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Well, can I have 15 seconds also?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: No, let’s move on, gentlemen.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’ll tell you what. If —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s not — we’re not horse trading. We’re having a debate. Let’s go on. Let’s talk about the cities. Because that’s where a majority of Americans live, in urban areas, and they’re facing a financial and social crisis. They’ve lost sources of tax revenue. The aid that once came from the federal and state governments has been drastically cut. There’s an epidemic of drugs, crime and violence. Their streets, their schools are like war zones. It’s becoming increasingly difficult to pay for public education, for transportation, for police and fire protection, the basic services that local government must provide.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Now, everybody says, talks about enterprise zones, that may be part of the solution, but what else are your administrations really going to be willing to do to help the cities?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle, it’s your turn to go first.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, Hal, enterprise zones are important and it’s an idea that the president has been pushing, and there’s been very strong reluctance on, with the Democratic Congress. We’ll continue to push it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We also want, Hal, to have home ownership. I was at a housing sub — a housing project in San Francisco several months ago and met with people that were trying to reclaim their neighborhood.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: They wanted home ownership. They didn’t want handouts. And I was with the Democrat mayor of San Francisco who was there supporting our idea. But when you look at the cities and you see the problems we have with crime, drugs, lack of jobs, I also want to point out one of the fundamental problems that we have in American cities and throughout America today, and that is the breakdown of the American family.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I know some people laugh about it when I talk about the breakdown of the family, but it’s true. 60 % of the kids that are born in our major cities today are born out of wedlock. We have too many divorces. We have too many fathers that aren’t assuming their responsibility. The breakdown of the family is a contributing factor to the problems that we have in urban America.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I think enterprise zones are good, but I think the problem is deeper than that. I think we are — you know, when I was — I ran a civilization for several years, a civilization of 3 to 4 hundred wonderful men. We had our own laws. We had our own, practically our own constitution. And I put up — I was the — I was the sovereign for a good bit of that. And I tried to analyze human predicaments in that microcosm of life in the — in the world. And I found out that when I really got down to putting out do’s and don’ts, and lots of these included take torture for this and that, and this and that, and never take any amnesty, for reasons they all understood and went along with. But one of the — we had an acronym, BACKUS, and each one of those B-a-c-k was something for which you — you had to make them hurt you before you did it. Bowing in public, making, making — getting on the radio and so forth. But at the end it was US, BACKUS. You got the double meaning there.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: But the US could be called the US, but it was Unity Over Self, Loners Make Out. Somehow we’re going to have to get some love in this country between races, and between rich and poor. You have got to have leaders — and they’re out there — who can do this with their bare hands, with — working with, with people on the scene.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore, please.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: George Bush’s urban policy has been a tale of 2 cities: the best of times for the very wealthy; the worst of times for everyone else. We have seen a decline in urban America under the Bush-Quayle administration. Bill Clinton and I want to change that, by creating good jobs, investing in infrastructure, new programs in job training and apprenticeship, welfare reform — to say to a mother with young children that if she gets a good job, her children are not going to lose their Medicaid benefits; incentives for investment in the inner city area, and, yes, enterprise zones. Vice President Quayle said they’re important, but George Bush eliminated them from his urban plan, and then —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Well, that’s not true.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And then, when they were included in a plan that the Congress passed, —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: We have been for enterprise zones —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — George Bush vetoed the enterprise zone law, the law that included them, for one reason: because that same bill raised taxes on those making more than $200,000 a year.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Let’s face up to it, Dan: your top priority really, isn’t it, to make sure that the very wealthy don’t have to pay any more taxes. We want to cut taxes on middle-income families and raise them on those making more than $200,000 a year.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: What plan is that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: And if we can take our approach, the cities will be much better off.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let’s start the discussion period right here. Go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: What plan is that that’s just going to raise taxes on those making over $200,000 a year? You may call that your plan, but everyone knows that you simply can’t get $150 billion in new taxes by raising the marginal tax rate to a top rate of 36 % and only tax those making $200,000 a year. It’s absolutely ridiculous. The top 2 % which you refer to, that gets you down to $64,000; then you have about a $40-billion shortfall — that gets you down to $36,000 a year. Everybody making more than $36,000 a year will have their taxes increased if Bill Clinton is president of the US.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And I don’t know how you’re going to go to urban America and say that raising taxes is good for you. I don’t know how you’re going to go to urban America and say, well, the best thing that we can offer is simply to raise taxes again. This is nothing more than a tax-and-spend platform. We’ve seen it before. It doesn’t work.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let me tell you about a story.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Can I respond to some of that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I’ve got a very good example —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Can I respond to some of that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — when we talk about families here, because I was meeting with some former gang members in Phoenix and Los Angeles and Albuquerque, New Mexico. And when I talked to those former gang members, here’s what they told me why they joined the gang. They said, well, joining a gang is like joining a family. I said, joining a family? Yes, because the gang offered support, it offered leadership, it offered comfort, it was a way to get ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Where have we come if joining a gang is like being a member of the family?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore, you wanted to respond?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And that’s why I think that families have to be strengthened, and you don’t strengthen the American family by raising taxes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: I do want to respond to that.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead, Senator, Admiral.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: George Bush and Dan Quayle want to protect the very wealthy. That is the group that has gotten all of the tax cuts under the Bush-Quayle administration. Nobody here who is middle income has gotten a tax cut because middle-income families have had tax increases under Bush and Quayle in order to finance the cuts for the very wealthy. That’s what trickle-down economics is all about. And they want to continue it.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We’re proposing to also require foreign corporations to pay the same taxes that American corporations do when they do business here in the US of America. George Bush has not been willing to enforce the laws and collect those taxes. We want to close that loophole and raise more money in that way.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator, can we stick to the cities, sir?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Excuse me?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Stick to the cities.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: All right. Well, he, he talked about ways to raise money to help the cities. What we’re proposing is to invest in the infrastructure in cities and have targeted tax incentives for investment right in inner city areas. The enterprise zones represent a part of our proposal also, and strengthening the family through welfare reform. And you know the Bush administration has cut out — has vetoed family leave, they have cut childhood immunization and college aid.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: If you don’t support parents and you don’t support children, how — how can you say you support families?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: How about supporting parents and the right to choose where their kids go to school, Al?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Do you support that?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let the parents — let the parents —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Do you want me to answer?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: — public or private schools?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Want me to answer?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We support the public school choice to go to any public school of your choice. What we don’t support — and listen to what they’re proposing — to take US taxpayer dollars and subsidize private schools. Now I’m all for private schools, but to use taxpayer dollars, when the people who get these little vouchers often won’t be able to afford the private school anyway, and the private school is not —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Al, I think, I think it’s important —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: — under any obligation to admit them, that is a ripoff of the US taxpayer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: That’s important. This is a very- -this is a very important issue. Choice in education is a very important issue.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Let him respond.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: And he said that he was not for choosing — giving the parents the right to choose to send their children to public schools. But it’s okay for the wealthy to choose to send their kids to private schools, but it’s not okay for the middle class and the working poor to choose where they want to send their kids to school.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I think that it’s time that all parents in America have a right to choose where they send their kids to school to get an education.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Admiral Stockdale, would you like to have the last word in this period?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I — I come down on the side of freedom of school choice. The — and there’s a lot of misunderstandings that I’ve heard here tonight, that I may have the answer to. The — starting at, you know, for the last, almost a decade, we’ve worried about our schools officially through Washington, and the president had a meeting of all the governors, and then they tried the conventional fixes for schools, that is, to increase the certification of — requirements for the teachers, to lengthen the school day, to lengthen the school year and nothing — this is a very brief overview of the thing — but nothing happened. And it’s time to change the school’s structure. In schools, bureaucracy is bad and autonomy is good. The only good schools —

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: — we have are those run by talented principals and devoted teachers, and they’re running their own show. How many times have I thrived? You know, the best thing I had when I ran that civilization, it succeeded, and it’s a landmark. The best thing I had going for me was I had no contact with Washington for all those years.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Could I respond?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: We have to go on. What I’m about to say doesn’t apply to the debate tonight; it applies to the campaign that’s been going on outside this auditorium. With 3 weeks to go, this campaign has at times been very ugly, with the tone being set by personal negative attacks.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: As candidates, how does it look from your viewpoint? And are these tactics really necessary? Admiral Stockdale — it’s your turn to go first.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: You know, I didn’t have my hearing aid turned on. Tell me again.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: (Laughter)

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: I’m sorry, sir. I was saying that at times this campaign has been very ugly with personal negative attacks. As a candidate, how does it look from where you are and are these tactics really necessary?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: Nasty attacks — well, I think there is a case to be made for putting emphasis on character over these issues that we’ve been batting back and forth and have a life of their own. Sure, you have to know where you’re going with your government, but character is the big variable in the success. Character of the leaders is the big variable in the success — long term success — of an administration.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I went to a friend of mine in New York some years ago and he was a president of a major TV network and he said, you know, I think we have messed up this whole — this election process — it was an election year — by stressing that — putting out the dogma that issues are the thing to talk about, not character.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: He said, I felt so strongly about this, I went back and read the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Read those debates. How do they come down? Douglas is all character. He knows all of the little stinky numbers these guys do. Abraham Lincoln had character. Thank God we got the right president in the Civil War.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: But that is a question that is a valid one, and you know, I would like to brag about the character of my boss.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay, Senator Gore.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: This election is about the future of our country, not about personal attacks against one candidate or another. Our nation is in trouble and it is appalling to me that with 10 million Americans out work, with the rest working harder for less money than they did 4 years ago, with the loss of 1.4 million manufacturing jobs in our nation, with the health care crisis, a crisis of crime and drugs and AIDS, substandard education, that George Bush would constantly try to level personal attacks at his opponent.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Now, this, of course, just reached a new low last week when he resorted to a classic McCarthyite technique of trying to smear Bill Clinton over a trip that he took as a student along with lots of other Rhodes Scholars who were invited to go to Russia. It’s a classic McCarthyite smear technique. I think the president of the US ought to apologize. I think that he insulted the intelligence of the American people and I’m awful proud that the American people rejected that tactic so overwhelmingly that he decided he had made a mistake. Do you think it was a mistake, too, Dan?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Okay. Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Let me answer the question.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Go ahead.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Hal, you said — and I wrote it down here — “personal negative attacks.” (Laughs) Has anyone been reading my press clippings for the last 4 years?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: But I happen to — I agree with one thing on — with Senator Gore, and that is that we ought to look to the future, and the future is, who’s going to be the next president of the US. And is it a negative attack and a personal attack to point out that Bill Clinton simply has trouble telling the truth? He said that he didn’t even demonstrate — he told the people in Arkansas in 1978. Then we find out he organized demonstrations. You know, I don’t care whether he demonstrated or didn’t demonstrate. The fact — the question is, tell the truth. Just tell us the truth. Today, Bill Clinton — excuse me — yesterday in Philadelphia on a radio show, just yesterday on a radio show, he attacked — Admiral, he attacks Ross Perot saying the media is giving Ross Perot a free ride. The press asked him when the klieg lights are on, said what do you mean by Ross Perot getting a free ride? He says I didn’t say that at all.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I mean, you can’t have it both ways. No, I don’t think that is a personal attack. What I find troubling with Bill Clinton is he can’t tell the truth. You cannot lead this great country of ours by misleading the people.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: All right, gentlemen, the control room advises me that in order to have time for your closing statements, which we certainly want, there simply is not going to be time for a discussion period on this particular topic.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: So let’s go to the closing statements. You have 2 minutes each. And we’ll start with Admiral Stockdale.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we’re seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don’t concentrate on where our grandchildren — the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is, as I have read in more than one article, a revolutionary; he’s got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how, if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art, to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: STOCKDALE
Text: And there’s no better man in the world to do that than that old artist, Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I’m in a room with people that aren’t the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We’ve got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped, and that’s what we’re about in the Perot campaign.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Thank you.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Senator Gore, your closing statement, sir.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Three weeks from today, our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on, which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times, or we can reach out for change. If we choose change, it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they’re no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors, Republicans and Democrats alike, as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: He’s moved 17,000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education, and again, he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Isn’t it time for a new approach, a new generation of ideas and leadership, to put our nation’s people first and to get our economy moving again?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately, it is a choice between hope and fear, a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are, as a nation, and we have a much brighter future.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: GORE
Text: Give us a chance. With your help, we’ll change this country and we can’t wait to get started.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: Vice President Quayle.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Thank you, Hal. I’d like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I’m sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that’s why we support choice in education.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I was in Beaumont, Texas, and met with small business people, and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there’s too much of a delay in getting an answer.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I was in Middletown, Ohio, talking to a welfare woman, where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I’m not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn’t have health insurance. Under President Bush’s health care reform package that woman won’t have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children, because she’ll have both.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: I was in Vilnius, Lithuania, Independence Square, speaking to 10,000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said - God bless America.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: Yes, in the next 4 years, as I said, somewhere, some time, there’s going to be a crisis, and you need to have a president that is qualified, has the experience, and has been tested. Not one time during this evening, during 90 minutes, did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: QUAYLE
Text: The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe — do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you, do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: That concludes this vice presidential debate. I’d like to thank Vice President Quayle, Senator Gore, Admiral Stockdale for being participants.

Title: October 13, 1992 Debate Transcript
Speaker: BRUNO
Text: The next presidential debate is scheduled for this Thursday at 9:00 PM Eastern Time at the University of Richmond in Richmond, Virginia. To all of our viewers and listeners, thank you and good night.
